Reason for Being Affected: Fungal disease caused by Venturia inaequalis, which overwinters in fallen leaves; cool, wet spring weather triggers spore release:contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}.
Symptoms: Dark olive-green to brown circular spots appear on leaves (often coalescing into larger areas and causing leaf distortion) and on fruit (rough, circular lesions), leading to misshapen fruit or premature fruit drop:contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}:contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}.
Recommended Solution: Sanitation: remove or shred fallen leaves (can spray 5% urea on leaf litter in autumn) to destroy overwintering fungus:contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}; plant resistant varieties:contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}. Chemical: protect new growth with timely fungicide sprays (e.g., mancozeb or other FRAC-rotated fungicides) from bud break through petal fall:contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}.
Recommended Fertilizer: Spray 5% urea (46-0-0) on fallen leaves in autumn to hasten leaf decomposition and reduce inoculum:contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}. Also maintain balanced N-P-K fertilization (per soil test) to keep trees vigorous.

Reason for Being Affected: Fungal disease caused by Botryosphaeria obtusa (Diplodia) that infects living or dead wood and fruit; trees stressed by drought, poor drainage, or fire blight are especially susceptible:contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}:contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}.
Symptoms: Fruit develop brown to black rot (often on blossom end) with concentric ring spots and firm, brown interior; infected apples may shrivel into mummies with black pycnidia:contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}. Leaves show distinctive 'frog-eye' spots (tan centers with reddish margins):contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}. Branches exhibit sunken, reddish-brown cankers.
Recommended Solution: Sanitation: prune out and destroy (burn or remove) all mummified fruit, cankered branches, and dead wood:contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}. Maintain tree vigor with proper pruning, watering, and site selection to reduce stress:contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}. Chemical: fungicides rarely needed; if used, broad-spectrum captan/sulfur sprays (as part of a scab spray program) can help control leaf spots:contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}.
Recommended Fertilizer: Apply balanced fertilizer (e.g., 10-10-10 N-P-K) each spring according to tree age/size to maintain vigor:contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}.

Reason for Being Affected: Rust fungus (Gymnosporangium spp.) requiring two hosts (apple/crabapple and juniper); overwinters in cedar galls. Wet spring weather produces orange jelly horns on cedar, releasing spores that infect apple leaves and fruit:contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}.
Symptoms: Bright yellow-orange spots on apple leaves in spring, often developing orange gelatinous spore horns on the underside:contentReference[oaicite:16]{index=16}; spots on fruit are larger and yellow-orange:contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}. Infected leaves may drop in dry conditions:contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}.
Recommended Solution: Cultural: remove nearby eastern red cedars or galls; plant rust-resistant apple/crabapple varieties:contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}. Chemical: apply protective fungicide sprays (e.g. myclobutanil, copper, sulfur) starting at bud break and repeat through bloom to protect new leaves:contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}.
Recommended Fertilizer: Maintain balanced nutrition (e.g. N-P-K fertilizer or compost) to support tree health; apply in early spring per guidelines:contentReference[oaicite:21]{index=21}.

Reason for Being Affected: No disease present; plant has ideal conditions and care.
Symptoms: Leaves and fruits are normal and free of spots or blemishes.
Recommended Solution: Maintain good orchard practices (proper pruning, irrigation, weed control, monitoring for pests).
Recommended Fertilizer: Apply balanced orchard fertilizer (e.g., 10-10-10 N-P-K) in spring for healthy growth.

Reason for Being Affected: No disease; soil and environment are favorable (acidic pH, proper moisture).
Symptoms: Leaf color is deep green, branches are vigorous, normal flowering and fruiting.
Recommended Solution: Maintain soil acidity (pH 4.5–5.5), mulch to conserve moisture, and remove weeds; monitor for pests.
Recommended Fertilizer: Apply acidic fertilizer (e.g., ammonium sulfate or specialized blueberry fertilizer) as per soil test.

Reason for Being Affected: No disease; good cultural conditions.
Symptoms: Green healthy leaves and unblemished fruit.
Recommended Solution: Provide adequate water, proper pruning, and pest monitoring; maintain plant hygiene.
Recommended Fertilizer: Apply balanced fertilizer (e.g., 10-10-10) in early spring for stone fruits.

Reason for Being Affected: Fungal pathogen Podosphaera clandestina that overwinters in buds and thrives in warm (70–80°F), humid conditions:contentReference[oaicite:22]{index=22}.
Symptoms: White, powdery fungal growth on the surface of young leaves, shoots or fruit; leaves may become distorted or drop if infected:contentReference[oaicite:23]{index=23}.
Recommended Solution: Protect new growth with fungicide sprays (apply soon after petal fall and repeat 2–3 weeks later):contentReference[oaicite:24]{index=24}; prune and thin canopy for air flow and remove infected shoots to reduce inoculum.
Recommended Fertilizer: Apply balanced fertilizer (e.g., 10-10-10) in spring to maintain vigorous growth.

Reason for Being Affected: Fungal disease caused by Cercospora zeae-maydis, which overwinters in crop residue; thrives in warm, humid conditions:contentReference[oaicite:25]{index=25}:contentReference[oaicite:26]{index=26}.
Symptoms: Elliptical to rectangular gray-brown lesions on corn leaves, 1/8\ wide by 2–3\" long
Recommended Solution: often bounded by leaf veins:contentReference[oaicite:27]{index=27}."
Recommended Fertilizer: Use resistant hybrids and crop rotation to non-hosts; tillage to bury residue; apply foliar fungicides under high disease risk:contentReference[oaicite:28]{index=28}.
column6: Ensure adequate fertility: side-dress nitrogen if needed during growing season.

Reason for Being Affected: Rust fungus Puccinia sorghi that overwinters in the south; spores blow north during summer. Favors cool (60–76°F), humid conditions with dew:contentReference[oaicite:29]{index=29}.
Symptoms: Numerous elongated reddish-brown pustules on both upper and lower leaf surfaces (and sheaths), turning dark brown as they age:contentReference[oaicite:30]{index=30}; heavy infections cause leaf yellowing or death.
Recommended Solution: Plant rust-resistant corn hybrids and maintain plant health. Apply fungicide early if rust pustules appear (best when applied before severe infection):contentReference[oaicite:31]{index=31}.
Recommended Fertilizer: Maintain adequate fertility; side-dress nitrogen as needed for corn growth.

Reason for Being Affected: No disease; seedbed and crop management are optimal.
Symptoms: Tall green stalks, full tassels and ears without leaf spots or deformation.
Recommended Solution: Maintain field hygiene and use crop rotation; monitor pests. Ensure proper irrigation.
Recommended Fertilizer: Side-dress with nitrogen fertilizer (e.g., urea or ammonium nitrate) during growing season.

Reason for Being Affected: Fungal disease by Setosphaeria turcica; overwinters in corn residue. Favored by prolonged leaf wetness (>6 hr) and moderate temperatures (64–81°F):contentReference[oaicite:32]{index=32}.
Symptoms: Long (1–6 inch) elliptical 'cigar-shaped' gray-green lesions on leaves that turn pale gray or tan; in severe cases, entire leaves may die:contentReference[oaicite:33]{index=33}.
Recommended Solution: Plant resistant corn hybrids and avoid continuous corn (rotate crops); tillage to reduce residue. Apply foliar fungicide early if lesions begin to coalesce.
Recommended Fertilizer: Side-dress nitrogen fertilizer as needed for corn development.

Reason for Being Affected: Fungal disease caused by Guignardia bidwellii, favored by warm (70–80°F), humid conditions and overhead moisture; overwinters in mummified fruit and canes:contentReference[oaicite:34]{index=34}.
Symptoms: Leaves: round tan lesions with dark brown edges; berries: initially brown and soft, later hard black shriveled 'mummies' with pycnidia:contentReference[oaicite:35]{index=35}. Shoots may have black lesions and girdle.
Recommended Solution: Sanitation: remove and destroy infected canes, leaves, and mummified berries (or bury them) to reduce inoculum:contentReference[oaicite:36]{index=36}. Apply protectant fungicides (e.g. sulfur/copper/mancozeb) from pre-bloom through 4–6 weeks post-bloom:contentReference[oaicite:37]{index=37}.
Recommended Fertilizer: Apply balanced fertilizer (e.g., 10-10-10) in spring to maintain vine vigor.

Reason for Being Affected: Complex fungal disease (Esca) involving Phaeomoniella and Phaeoacremonium spp.; favored by vine wood wounds and stress:contentReference[oaicite:38]{index=38}.
Symptoms: Small dark spots ('measles') on berries, often coalescing into black blisters; leaves may show interveinal 'tiger stripe' discoloration:contentReference[oaicite:39]{index=39}; can cause sudden vine collapse in severe cases.
Recommended Solution: No reliable chemical control. Remove and destroy infected fruit and vines; provide good vineyard sanitation and treat pruning wounds; plant resistant/rootstock if available.
Recommended Fertilizer: Apply balanced fertilizer to maintain vine vigor (no specific disease control effect).

Reason for Being Affected: Caused by the fungus Pseudocercospora vitis (formerly Isariopsis viticola); disease is favored by warm, humid late-season conditions:contentReference[oaicite:40]{index=40}.
Symptoms: Large, irregular angular leaf spots: initially dull red-brown, later turning black and brittle:contentReference[oaicite:41]{index=41}; minor defoliation may occur under severe infection.
Recommended Solution: Apply protective fungicides (e.g., copper, mancozeb) early in the season as for other grape diseases; remove infected leaves to reduce inoculum.
Recommended Fertilizer: Use balanced fertilizer to ensure vine vigor (no direct effect on this disease).

Reason for Being Affected: No disease; vines are well managed.
Symptoms: Vigorous canes with healthy leaves, and developing clusters without rot.
Recommended Solution: Prune and train vines for good air circulation; scout for pests and diseases.
Recommended Fertilizer: Apply balanced fertilizer (based on soil test) in early spring (e.g., ammonium nitrate or 10-10-10).

Reason for Being Affected: Bacterial disease caused by Candidatus Liberibacter spp., spread by the Asian citrus psyllid insect; thrives in warm citrus regions:contentReference[oaicite:42]{index=42}.
Symptoms: Chlorotic leaf mottling (asymmetrical yellowing), twig dieback, and stunted, off-color fruit that remain green or develop bitter flavor:contentReference[oaicite:43]{index=43}; infected trees eventually decline and die.
Recommended Solution: No cure exists. Manage by controlling psyllid vectors (insecticides, traps) and removing infected trees to reduce spread. Use disease-free nursery stock and strict sanitation.
Recommended Fertilizer: Intensive nutritional programs (e.g., zinc, iron, and nitrogen foliar sprays) can help maintain tree health but do not cure the disease.

Reason for Being Affected: Bacterial disease by Xanthomonas campestris pv. pruni; favored by warm, wet conditions and spread by rain, windblown sand and pruning wounds:contentReference[oaicite:44]{index=44}.
Symptoms: Leaves develop small dark spots (often clustered at leaf tips) with yellow halos:contentReference[oaicite:45]{index=45}. Fruit develop corky, pitted lesions that may crack and ooze gum:contentReference[oaicite:46]{index=46}.
Recommended Solution: Plant resistant cultivars and prune in dry weather. Apply fixed copper or bactericidal sprays (e.g., oxytetracycline) from delayed dormancy through shuck split:contentReference[oaicite:47]{index=47}. Sanitize tools and remove infected twigs.
Recommended Fertilizer: Apply balanced fertilizer (e.g., 10-10-10) in spring to maintain tree health.

Reason for Being Affected: No disease; good orchard conditions.
Symptoms: Normal green leaves and healthy peach development.
Recommended Solution: Perform annual pruning and thinning; ensure adequate water.
Recommended Fertilizer: Apply balanced fertilizer (e.g., 10-10-10) in spring according to tree age.

Reason for Being Affected: Bacterial disease by Xanthomonas spp.; favored by warm, humid weather and overhead irrigation, which spreads bacteria on pepper leaves and fruit:contentReference[oaicite:48]{index=48}.
Symptoms: On leaves: water-soaked spots that turn tan-brown and coalesce, often causing yellowing and defoliation:contentReference[oaicite:49]{index=49}. On fruit: raised brown to black scabby lesions that render fruit unmarketable:contentReference[oaicite:50]{index=50}.
Recommended Solution: Plant resistant pepper varieties:contentReference[oaicite:51]{index=51} and avoid overhead watering. Apply bactericidal sprays (copper-based compounds plus mancozeb) at frequent intervals during warm, wet weather:contentReference[oaicite:52]{index=52}. Remove crop debris and rotate fields.
Recommended Fertilizer: Balanced vegetable fertilization as per crop requirements (e.g., 5-10-10 before planting and side-dress N).

Reason for Being Affected: No disease; favorable growing conditions.
Symptoms: Green foliage and healthy fruit without spots.
Recommended Solution: Use good soil, proper spacing, stake support, and monitor pests.
Recommended Fertilizer: Apply balanced vegetable fertilizer (e.g., 10-10-10) at planting and side-dress as needed.

Reason for Being Affected: Fungal disease by Alternaria solani; overwinters on potato debris and weeds. Infection favored by warm (above 80°F) and wet conditions (dew, irrigation):contentReference[oaicite:53]{index=53}.
Symptoms: Circular to irregular brown lesions on older leaves, often with concentric rings ('target spots'); severely infected leaves turn yellow and drop:contentReference[oaicite:54]{index=54}. Infected tubers develop brown, corky dry rot in soil.
Recommended Solution: Maintain vigorous, non-stressed plants through proper irrigation and fertilization:contentReference[oaicite:55]{index=55}; remove infected debris. Use later-maturing resistant varieties. Apply fungicides (e.g., chlorothalonil or strobilurins) at first sign of disease:contentReference[oaicite:56]{index=56}.
Recommended Fertilizer: Apply balanced fertilizer (including adequate nitrogen) as recommended to promote strong foliage:contentReference[oaicite:57]{index=57}.

Reason for Being Affected: No disease; optimal tuber-growing conditions.
Symptoms: Healthy green vines and normal tuber development underground.
Recommended Solution: Practice crop rotation and hilling; control insects (e.g., Colorado potato beetle).
Recommended Fertilizer: Apply balanced fertilizer (e.g., 5-10-10) at planting to promote tuber growth.

Reason for Being Affected: Oomycete pathogen Phytophthora infestans; spreads via infected seed tubers, volunteers, and cull piles. Favored by cool, wet conditions (50–78°F, >90% humidity):contentReference[oaicite:58]{index=58}.
Symptoms: On leaves: irregular water-soaked green lesions that rapidly turn brown to black, often with white downy growth on undersides in humid conditions:contentReference[oaicite:59]{index=59}. Stems show brown-black lesions; tubers develop firm brown decay under the skin.
Recommended Solution: Use certified seed and remove volunteer plants/cull piles to reduce inoculum. Provide good air circulation (avoid overhead irrigation at night). Apply protective fungicides preventively and at 7–10 day intervals during high risk periods:contentReference[oaicite:60]{index=60}:contentReference[oaicite:61]{index=61}.
Recommended Fertilizer: Maintain balanced soil fertility (e.g., N-P-K as per soil test) to encourage rapid canopy development and reduce stress.

Reason for Being Affected: No disease; plants are well cared for.
Symptoms: Healthy canes and leaves with normal berry production.
Recommended Solution: Prune properly after harvest; remove old canes.
Recommended Fertilizer: Apply balanced fertilizer (e.g., 10-10-10) after fruiting.

Reason for Being Affected: No disease; fields are managed well.
Symptoms: Healthy trifoliate leaves and pod set with no lesions.
Recommended Solution: Rotate crops and inoculate seeds; manage weeds.
Recommended Fertilizer: Legumes fix N; apply phosphorus and potassium based on soil test.

Reason for Being Affected: Fungal disease (primarily Podosphaera xanthii) favored by warm (68–81°F), humid conditions; spores spread by wind later in season:contentReference[oaicite:62]{index=62}.
Symptoms: White powdery fungal growth on upper and lower leaf surfaces, expanding into large patches:contentReference[oaicite:63]{index=63}. Heavily infected leaves yellow and wither; plants weaken, producing fewer/smaller fruit:contentReference[oaicite:64]{index=64}.
Recommended Solution: Plant resistant cucumber/squash varieties; ensure good air circulation (space plants, stake vines). Apply fungicides (sulfur or specific mildew fungicides) at first signs of infection if necessary:contentReference[oaicite:65]{index=65}.
Recommended Fertilizer: Maintain balanced fertilization (avoid excessive nitrogen); healthy plants resist disease better.

Reason for Being Affected: No disease; optimal conditions.
Symptoms: Green foliage and healthy fruit without spots.
Recommended Solution: Use clean planting stock; rotate beds and control weeds.
Recommended Fertilizer: Apply balanced fertilizer (e.g., 8-10-10) after fruiting.

Reason for Being Affected: Fungal disease by Diplocarpon earlianum (teleomorph) / Marssonina fragariae (anamorph); favored by warm, wet conditions (68–86°F) with leaf wetness:contentReference[oaicite:66]{index=66}.
Symptoms: Leaves with irregular dark purple spots with black centers; spots may coalesce, turning the leaf tissue between spots red-purple. Severely infected leaves turn brown, dry, and curl at edges:contentReference[oaicite:67]{index=67}; petioles develop sunken lesions.
Recommended Solution: Use resistant varieties and plant in sunny, well-drained areas:contentReference[oaicite:68]{index=68}. Ensure good airflow (space plants, remove weeds) and avoid overhead irrigation at night:contentReference[oaicite:69]{index=69}. Remove and destroy infected foliage after harvest. Fungicides at flowering or after renovation can reduce disease pressure.
Recommended Fertilizer: Apply balanced fertilizer and avoid excessive nitrogen, which can increase disease severity:contentReference[oaicite:70]{index=70}.

Reason for Being Affected: Bacterial disease by Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicatoria, seedborne and also in debris/volunteers. Spread by rain/splashes and warm, humid weather:contentReference[oaicite:71]{index=71}.
Symptoms: Small water-soaked spots on leaves turning dark brown/black (often merging); on young fruit: slightly sunken spots that enlarge, turn brown and scabby:contentReference[oaicite:72]{index=72}.
Recommended Solution: Use certified disease-free seed and transplants; rotate crops and remove cull piles. Avoid overhead irrigation and wetting foliage. Begin protective copper sprays early and repeat every 10–14 days under favorable conditions:contentReference[oaicite:73]{index=73} (combine with mancozeb to overcome copper resistance).
Recommended Fertilizer: Maintain balanced fertilization to promote vigorous growth.

Reason for Being Affected: Fungal disease by Alternaria solani; spores spread by wind and rain splash and require moisture and moderate temperatures to infect:contentReference[oaicite:74]{index=74}.
Symptoms: On lower leaves first: black or brown circular spots (1 cm) with concentric rings; lesions can coalesce causing leaf yellowing. Fruit develop sunken brown spots with target-like rings:contentReference[oaicite:75]{index=75}.
Recommended Solution: Avoid overhead irrigation and remove lower infected leaves. Rotate crops and mulch to reduce soil splash. Apply protectant fungicides (e.g., copper, chlorothalonil) at first sign of spots, repeating every 7–10 days during humid weather:contentReference[oaicite:76]{index=76}.
Recommended Fertilizer: Maintain balanced nutrition; avoid excessive nitrogen which can increase susceptibility.

Reason for Being Affected: Oomycete Phytophthora infestans, like in potatoes; spread by spores from infected potatoes/tomatoes and favored by cool, humid conditions (60–78°F, >90% RH):contentReference[oaicite:77]{index=77}.
Symptoms: Watersoaked green spots on leaves rapidly enlarge to purplish-brown, greasy lesions; white fungal growth often visible on undersides. Stems blacken at lesions. Fruit develop firm brown rot on shoulders:contentReference[oaicite:78]{index=78}.
Recommended Solution: Plant resistant tomato cultivars if available. Eliminate volunteer solanaceous hosts (tomato, potato, nightshade). Avoid overhead watering. Apply protectant fungicides (e.g., chlorothalonil or copper) preventatively when conditions favor late blight:contentReference[oaicite:79]{index=79}.
Recommended Fertilizer: Maintain balanced N-P-K fertilization to support healthy foliage.

Reason for Being Affected: Fungal disease caused by Passalora fulva (formerly Fulvia fulva); thrives in humid (>85% RH), warm greenhouse/high tunnel conditions:contentReference[oaicite:80]{index=80}.
Symptoms: Yellowish spots on upper leaf surfaces and olive-green velvety mold on undersides; leaves eventually turn brown and die:contentReference[oaicite:81]{index=81}. Infected blossoms turn black; fruit shoulder can develop sunken black leathery areas.
Recommended Solution: Use drip irrigation and ensure good ventilation (fans, vents) to reduce humidity:contentReference[oaicite:82]{index=82}. Space and prune plants to improve air flow. Remove and destroy infected foliage. Apply appropriate fungicides (multiple modes of action) preventively.
Recommended Fertilizer: Maintain balanced nutrient levels to promote healthy foliage (no specific fertilizer effect on mold).

Reason for Being Affected: Fungal disease by Septoria lycopersici; survives in plant debris. Thrives when lower leaf canopy is dense (high humidity, long leaf wetness):contentReference[oaicite:83]{index=83}.
Symptoms: On lower leaves: small (¼ inch) round spots with grayish-white centers and dark brown borders:contentReference[oaicite:84]{index=84}. Spots enlarge and coalesce, causing yellowing and leaf drop from the bottom up.
Recommended Solution: Remove and destroy affected leaves or entire plants to improve air flow. Avoid overhead irrigation and space plants to reduce humidity. Apply protective fungicides (e.g., chlorothalonil or copper) before symptoms, repeating regularly:contentReference[oaicite:85]{index=85}.
Recommended Fertilizer: Maintain balanced fertility; avoid excessive nitrogen to limit lush growth that favors disease.

Reason for Being Affected: Pest (arachnid) Tetranychus urticae thrives in hot, dry conditions; outbreaks are aggravated by excess nitrogen fertilization:contentReference[oaicite:86]{index=86}:contentReference[oaicite:87]{index=87}.
Symptoms: Leaves develop fine pale stippling or bronze discoloration as mites suck chlorophyll; heavy infestations produce fine webbing. Severely infested leaves become yellow or reddish-brown and drop:contentReference[oaicite:88]{index=88}.
Recommended Solution: Use miticides or insecticidal soaps/acaricides (e.g., abamectin, bifenazate) according to label; target undersides of leaves. Introduce or conserve predatory mites (e.g., Phytoseiulus persimilis). Avoid broad-spectrum insecticides. Increase humidity (overhead irrigation) can help suppress mites:contentReference[oaicite:89]{index=89}:contentReference[oaicite:90]{index=90}.
Recommended Fertilizer: Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization; maintain balanced N-P-K levels.

Reason for Being Affected: Fungal disease by Corynespora cassiicola; favored by moderate warm temperatures (70–80°F) and overhead moisture:contentReference[oaicite:91]{index=91}.
Symptoms: Small tan to light brown spots with dark margins appear on inner foliage; lesions coalesce leading to defoliation ('melting out'). Fruit develop small brown sunken flecks that enlarge into large pitted areas:contentReference[oaicite:92]{index=92}.
Recommended Solution: Sanitation: remove/destroy crop debris and weeds (alternate hosts). Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization to prevent lush growth. Fungicide: apply protectant sprays (chlorothalonil/mancozeb) preventively; systemic fungicides (strobilurins, famoxadone) improve control as needed.
Recommended Fertilizer: Avoid over-fertilizing with nitrogen; maintain balanced nutrition (e.g., N-P-K as per soil test) to reduce lush foliage development.

Reason for Being Affected: Viral disease (ToMV, a tobamovirus) that can be introduced on infected seed, transplants, or through contaminated tools/hands; spread is facilitated by handling plants and also by thrips/aphids:contentReference[oaicite:94]{index=94}.
Symptoms: Mottled light and dark green leaf pattern, often with distortion or stunting; older leaves may show necrotic patches. Fruit may have irregular raised or sunken discolored spots ('mosaic') and uneven ripening:contentReference[oaicite:95]{index=95}.
Recommended Solution: Use resistant (Tobamovirus-resistant) tomato cultivars:contentReference[oaicite:96]{index=96}. Remove and destroy infected plants. Practice strict sanitation: disinfect tools, wash hands, and avoid tobacco use near plants. Rotate crops and use virus-free seed/transplants.
Recommended Fertilizer: Maintain balanced soil fertility; healthy plants may better tolerate virus infection.

Reason for Being Affected: Viral disease spread by the whitefly (Bemisia tabaci) feeding on plants; no cure once infected:contentReference[oaicite:97]{index=97}.
Symptoms: Young leaves show interveinal yellowing and upward curling; overall plant is stunted and bushy with short internodes:contentReference[oaicite:98]{index=98}. Flower drop and severe yield loss occur in infected plants.
Recommended Solution: Plant TYLCV-resistant varieties (multiple cultivars available). Control whiteflies with insecticides and physical barriers: use reflective mulches, UV-blocking screens, and remove infected plants promptly:contentReference[oaicite:99]{index=99}:contentReference[oaicite:100]{index=100}.
Recommended Fertilizer: Maintain balanced nutrition; avoid excess nitrogen which may exacerbate foliage lushness.

Reason for Being Affected: No disease; plant is healthy under good care.
Symptoms: Unblemished leaves and normal tomato growth.
Recommended Solution: Provide support (stakes), regulate watering, and monitor for pests and diseases.
Recommended Fertilizer: Apply balanced fertilizer (e.g., 5-10-10 at planting, side-dress 10-10-10 midseason) for vigorous growth.
